bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Philip Showalter Hench, September 7, 1941

div1.p: Kean expresses reservations about allowing Laura Wood Roper to view any contentious material in the Reed family letters.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Philip Showalter Hench, September 7, 1941
div1.opener:
2804 N STREET, N. W.
WASHINGTON, D. C.
Sunday
Morning.
Sept. 7, 1941
My dear Dr Hench
div1.p:
I have just received your
Special Delivery Air mail letter
of yesterday and I realize with
regret that it was my negligence
in not answering specifically and
promptly your question about the
family letters that Mrs. Blossom
Reed loaned to you, that has
caused the delay in sending the
letter & inclosures to Mrs. Laura Wood.
She came to see me on Aug. 28 and
as I had your letter of the 25th inclos-
ing the carbon copy of your letter
to her we were both surprised
that she had not gotten the original.
AC
K
2
I felt perfect confidence in your
judgment is not giving her any of
the contentious material, and,
about the Reed letter, I do not
know exactly what the Reed
family has lent you and hesi-
tated to express an opinion.
So I have called up Gen W. L.
Reed just-now and asked him about his
sister and about your letting
Miss Wood have copies of the
letters of his father that his
sister has let you see and use
in your discretion. He said that
he was quite willing to trust to
your discretion as to their use
but as the point was put up to
him he did not know any thing
Kean to Hench
3
2804 N STREET, N. W.
WASHINGTON, D. C.
about Miss Wood and he was inclin-
ed not to do anything that might
afterward distress his mother or
his sister. I told him that I felt
also there was no reason for our
taking any chances and I recalled
that his mother used to be a little
sensitive about the “love letters” being
published. So we agreed that
it would be just as well not to
give her any that had not been
published already. Then he added
“I would hate to have her told that
the family objected to her having
them, couldn't you arrange it without
that”? I was a little amused at
this but said “certainly.” So I will
advise you that in my opinion as
these letters belong to Blossom Reed
AC
K
4
they should not been passed
around to other hands without
her permission. So you can tell
Miss Wood that and if she
comes to see me this week I
will tell her that it was my
oversight in failing to answer
your question that caused the
delay, and will give her that answer
myself. Gen. Reed said that
Blossom is getting on finely
at Walter Reed and is out
in the open air every day.
He or his wife sees her every
day but she is not allowed to
see other visitors. I was amused
at you having found Lawrence (Gen. R.)
not a satisfactory correspondent.
He has a reputation for not insur-
ing letters and when he was made
Kean to Hench
5
2804 N STREET, N. W.
WASHINGTON, D. C.
Inspector General. I phoned to his
mother and gave her my felicita-
tions and added, I was not going
to write a note of congratulation to
Lawrence because he had never
answered an important letter
that I had written him. Her reply
was “Oh you mustn't mind that
in Lawrence he doesn't write to me
either. He never writes a letter
if he can help it.”

So you see you need not expect
to get any details out of Law-
rence. I hope that you will
take time to read the letter to the
New York Times that I sent you
and Dr. L. O. Howard's letter about
it with his quotations from his
letter from Major Reed. I want them
AC
K
6
back but I am not in any hurry
about it. You do not mention
having received Truby's 165 page
Sketch of the 4.7. Episode as I
am sure he has not yet sent you
a copy. Please let me know
about this for you must see it
at once. Gen. Ireland came over
to get it as soon as I phoned
him it had come and was
immensely pleased with it.
I must stop now and get this
off but I cannot do so without
thanking you for the very handsome
thing that you said in your letter
to Miss Laura Wood about the “Trio
Kean-Truby-Ireland”. But you should
put Ireland first. He is really
a great as well as a very good man.
